results.title: Warriors
results.brief_description: SBS TV has collected together a group of independently made Australian documentaries on various aspects of war in the late twentieth century as it has affected the lives of individual Australians.

results.title: Pieces in the Puzzle
results.creator_credit: Christine Sammers and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Warriors”.
A program on women in war. Six Australian women discuss their experiences in, and consequent attitudes to, war. The first half of the program focuses on World War II and features Polish ex-Army officer, Anna Kosinski, who was imprisoned by the Nazis in Warsaw; Ruby Boye-Jones, ex-WRAN coast-watcher on the Solomon Islands and Gwen Campbell, ex-WAAF Wing Commander who served in Australia. The second half of the program turns to three women in war-torn Third World countries - ABC political journalist, Mary Delahunty, in El Salvador in 1982; political filmmaker, Fionna Douglas, in Eritrea and Mozambique; and horticulturalist, Ruth Beilin, working on an agricultural development project in Mozambique.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christine Sammers and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: Flying down to Rio
results.creator_credit: Thornton Freeland and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: This wonderful nostalgic film celebrates not only the Hollywood musical but more importantly and historically, it was also the first film that Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire teamed together and set the world alight with their magical dance movements. On-screen dancing would never be the same again. Electrifying, mesmerising, Rogers and Astaire outshone even the top-billed stars Dolores Del Rio, Gene Raymond and Raul Roulien. Forget the plot, just enjoy the whole musical experience.

results.title: The Sword and the Flower
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Paul Rea and Cinetel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Warriors”.
For some Australian ex-servicemen, wartime experiences have created permanent feelings of bitterness towards the Japanese. For others, like the men interviewed in this program, their contact with the Japanese led to a completely different attitude to war and their former enemies. Those interviewed include Norman Sparnon, ex-Major in Australian Army Intelligence who served as an interpreter in New Guinea and post-war Japan, George Beard who recalls his experiences in a Japanese POW camp in Thailand, Gordon Parker and Alan Pedder who both returned with war brides from Japan, Stephen Kelen, the only Australian soldier in Hiroshima on the first anniversary of the Bomb and Kenneth Wybrow, a barrister who assists the mixed-blood children left behind in Japan by Australian servicemen.

results.title: Flowers of Rethymnon
results.creator_credit: Colin South, John Tatoulis and Media World
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Warriors”.
A drama-documentary based on the memoirs of Lewis Lind. Lew Lind was a member of the Australian 2/11 Battalion, 3 Company, who defended Rethymnon in Crete against the German invasion in 1941. Following the German occupation of Crete, Lind was imprisoned in a POW camp from which he escaped with three other soldiers. This film uses interviews with Lind during his return to Crete in the 80s and re-enactments of the wartime experiences of Lind and fellow soldier, Dick Plant, who were sheltered by the Cretans from the Nazis. A notable feature of the program is the archival German newsreel footage on the invasion of Crete.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin South, John Tatoulis and Media World

results.title: Fly Peewee fly
results.creator_credit: Sally Riley, Adrienne Parr, Film Australia and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: A young Aboriginal boy, Robbie is in the midst of the conflict between his father and his grandmother. Robbie’s grandmother is white and wants to give Robbie every advantage, while Robbie’s aboriginal father is searching for his own identity and place. A warm story about fragile but meaningful family relationships.

results.title: Flubber
results.creator_credit: Les Mayfield, John Hughes, Ricardo Mestres, Great Oaks and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: In this colourful remake of ‘The Absent Minded Professor’ (1961), Robin Williams plays Professor Philip Brainard, a brilliant off the wall inventor with an unfortunate short term memory. Flubber, his latest creation is a green rubber-like substance, which has the capacity to give objects flight. Potentially a gold mine for the professor and his college (which is near bankruptcy), the invention receives the unwelcome attention of Brainard’s spiteful nemesis Wilson Croft (Christopher McDonald), who has his own plans for the gravity-defying matter. The romantic subplot which involves a bizarre love triangle between Brainard, his long suffering fiance Sara (Marcia Gay Harden), and a female robot with a jealous streak called Weebo (Jodi Benson), give the film some surprisingly poignant moments, mainly due to Harden’s tender performance. Music by Danny Elfman and screenplay by John Hughes and Bill Walsh.

constellations_other.name: Gooey goo goo
constellations_other.description: The special effects used in Symbiosis are curiously similar to some sticky Oscar-winning movies.

results.title: Floyd on Oz. - Volume 3.
results.creator_credit: David Pritchard, John Chase, Pam Stockley and Stockley Chase Productions
results.brief_description: Keith Floyd concludes his culinary journey around Australia with visits to the Northern Territory and Queensland. Highlights include his attempt to interest some truckies in a gourmet lunch of chicken, a meal cooked in a pit on a Queensland beach and mud crabs cooked by a rain forest river in the company of an Aboriginal dance troupe.

results.title: Fluxfilm anthology
results.brief_description: The Fluxus movement is made up of many artists blending visual arts, music and literature. The movement was founded in 1962 and has been compared to Dada and Surrealism. The artists include performance artists and video artists whose work is influenced by mystical thinking, irony and sometimes LSD. In this anthology compiled by the founder of the Fluxus movement, George Maciunas, and then later, Maeva Aubert, thirty seven pieces are gathered. Some of the videos are meant to be viewed in a loop, others use found footage and others create visual effects with a high-speed camera. The pieces range from 10 seconds to 10 minutes in length. Some of the films were screened in New York as part of the ‘happenings’ of the avant-garde. The works are often playful, undefinable reactions to everyday life. The search for meaning in life mixed with reflective, nonverbal strangeness. The artists are not necessarily known as filmmakers and include Nam June Paik, Yoko Ono, John Cale, Mike Parr, Robert Watts and Dick Higgens.

results.title: Floyd on Oz. - Volume 1.
results.creator_credit: David Pritchard, John Chase, Pam Stockley and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: In Sydney Floyd cooks a fish chowder for Sydney seafood supremo, Peter Doyle and finishes with pies and peas at the famous Harry’s Cafe de Wheels. In Tasmania Floyd creates seasonal autumn dishes. In Victoria Floyd becomes the cook for legendary horseman Jack Lovick. And in South Australia Floyd tastes some “Aussie” food: yabbies, razorfish and kangaroo-tail soup.
